structural_unit_name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

description.en: The course examines the central themes, theories, and concepts of the contemporary study of comparative politics. By gaining a knowledge of key concerns in the field, students will develop an understanding of how political institutions, actors, and processes operate around the world and what implications these arrangements have on democracy, society, and the economy. Importantly, the course will discuss and critically assess the ways in which political systems are changing in the era of technological transformation and how these developments influence the present and the future of liberal democracy
description.et: Kursus võtab vaatluse alla võrdleva poliitika, mis on poliitikateaduste üks suurimaid aladistsipliine, peamised teemad, teooriad ja mõisted. Ülevaade võrdleva poliitika põhiküsimustest annab tudengile arusaamise sellest, kuidas poliitilised protsessid ja nende erinevad osapooled erinevates riikides üle maailma tegutsevad ning millised tagajärjed nendel mustritel on demokraatiale, ühiskonnale ja majandusele. Olulise komponendina analüüsib kursus seda, millist mõju avaldavad poliitilistele süsteemidele tehnoloogilised muutused ning kuidas see seostub liberaalse demokraatia oleviku ja tulevikuga.

objectives.en: Explored through the comparison of political systems, this course provides the insights needed to understand democracy today and the challenges faced by democratic governments in the rapidly changing world. The course gives an understanding of the relationships between individuals, political actors, and democratic processes across different political systems of the world, and analyses contemporary challenges to these interactions.
objectives.et: Võttes aluseks erinevate poliitiliste süsteemide võrdluse, keskendub kursus sellele, kuidas mõista demokraatiat ja selle ees seisvaid väljakutseid tänases kiiresti muutuvas maailmas. Kursus annab ülevaate sellest, millised on suhted indiviidide, poliitiliste institutsioonide ja demokraatlike protsesside vahel erinevates poliitilistes süsteemides üle maailma ning analüüsib probleeme, millega need osapooled digitaalsel ajastul silmitsi seisavad

learning_outcomes.en: At the end of the course, students will be able to (1) discuss the main theoretical and empirical debates of the key concerns of comparative politics; (2) explain the relationships between individuals, actors, and democratic processes across different political systems, (3) evaluate critically the challenges to liberal democracy in the digital era, and (4) analyse these issues comparatively.
learning_outcomes.et: Kursuse läbinud üliõpilased oskavad (1) arutleda võrdleva poliitika peamiste teoreetiliste ja empiiriliste küsimuste üle; (2) selgitada, kuidas suhestuvad erinevates poliitilistes süsteemides omavahel indiviidid, poliitilised osalejad ja demokraatlikud protsessid; (3) hinnata kriitiliselt peamisi väljakutseid, millega liberaalne demokraatia digitaalsel ajastul silmitsi seisab ning (4) neid küsimusi võrdlevalt analüüsida.

independent_work.et: The independent work of the course includes readings that are required for each week, as well as a variety of assignments, some of which will be completed outside of class.

grade_preconditions.et:
Students will complete the following assignments, both in class and outside of class (more details are provided on Moodle for each activity): 

Minute papers, completed in class, will ask students to summarize key lessons from a seminar or classroom activity 

Assignments will include questions on key concepts and lessons, as well as analyses of related material. Revisions and resubmissions are encouraged. 

Active and informed participation is a key component of the course. I strive to create a class environment that encourages participation - so that all can benefit from the diverse insights and experiences that everyone brings. 

The cross-university blog is part of the Democratic Erosion project - a partnership between students and researchers at over 70 universities that seeks to analyze the global backsliding of democracy. Students will contribute to the online discussion blog, using theories of democratic backsliding to examine a specific current event. Students will also reply to at least one other participating student from another university. 

At the end of the semester, students will create a Democratic innovation infographic, examining one democratic innovation that they think should be imported from abroad to improve Estonia's democracy. They will share their project during the last class session and will participate in a peer-reviewed process. A 3-page paper will accompany the infographic.

grade_evaluation.et:
The maximum final result is 100 points. The student can receive up to 30 points for the formative and up to 70 points for the summative assignment. The final grade will be calculated as follows: 

91-100 points -> A 
81-90 points -> B 
71-80 points -> C 
61-70 points -> D 
51-60 points -> E 
0-51 points -> F
